data.title: Thames TV 55 Years Old - Page 4
data.meta_description: If you continue walking up Tottenham Court Road and cross over Euston Road and keep going up Hampstead Road you will find about two turnings up on the left hand side William Road.
data.text:
I think Thames and LWT were talking to each other early 90s to form a shared playout and news service , should they both have won the 1991 round ?

In the end it happened with Carlton, but quite honestly it would have happened if either Thames or LWT (or both) had lost their franchise(s)

Interesting that Carlton improved local regional programming but could not match Thames in terms of programming for the ITV network. If you could have the best of Thames and Carlton you would have the perfect service.

If you continue walking up Tottenham Court Road and cross over Euston Road and keep going up Hampstead Road you will find about two turnings up on the left hand side William Road. I remember when ITV first became available on satellite, when testing you would see colour bars with a black bar accross the middle with the William Road ident. So there must be switching and distribution facilities along there. So Stephen St. TCR, BT Tower, William Road and of course up to 1993 Thames Euston, all within close proximity.

If you continue walking up Tottenham Court Road and cross over Euston Road and keep going up Hampstead Road you will find about two turnings up on the left hand side William Road. I remember when ITV first became available on satellite, when testing you would see colour bars with a black bar accross the middle with the William Road ident. So there must be switching and distribution facilities along there. So Stephen St. TCR, BT Tower, William Road and of course up to 1993 Thames Euston, all within close proximity.

I think Thames and LWT were talking to each other early 90s to form a shared playout and news service , should they both have won the 1991 round ?

In the end it happened with Carlton, but quite honestly it would have happened if either Thames or LWT (or both) had lost their franchise(s)

Interesting that Carlton improved local regional programming but could not match Thames in terms of programming for the ITV network. If you could have the best of Thames and Carlton you would have the perfect service.

Principally thanks to London Tonight, a full one hour local news programme produced by the newly formed LNN and presented by Alastair Stewart, with at times Mary Nightingale co presenting. All done from Studio 7 at LWT on the South Bank with real windows and proper backdrop of the River Thames.

Thames could be considered older if you count the ABC/Rediffusion years. Wonder what ITV would have looked like if Thames had retained the franchise and Granada had lost their's.

I think LE wise itv would have had more variety, but it would have been all the poorer without Granada and dare I say no CS. The ideal solutionwould have been if all the franchise holders had not lost their licences.

I think Thames and LWT were talking to each other early 90s to form a shared playout and news service , should they both have won the 1991 round ?

In the end it happened with Carlton, but quite honestly it would have happened if either Thames or LWT (or both) had lost their franchise(s)

Interesting that Carlton improved local regional programming but could not match Thames in terms of programming for the ITV network. If you could have the best of Thames and Carlton you would have the perfect service.

Principally thanks to London Tonight, a full one hour local news programme produced by the newly formed LNN and presented by Alastair Stewart, with at times Mary Nightingale co presenting. All done from Studio 7 at LWT on the South Bank with real windows and proper backdrop of the River Thames.

I think Thames and LWT were talking to each other early 90s to form a shared playout and news service , should they both have won the 1991 round ?

In the end it happened with Carlton, but quite honestly it would have happened if either Thames or LWT (or both) had lost their franchise(s)

Interesting that Carlton improved local regional programming but could not match Thames in terms of programming for the ITV network. If you could have the best of Thames and Carlton you would have the perfect service.

Principally thanks to London Tonight, a full one hour local news programme produced by the newly formed LNN and presented by Alastair Stewart, with at times Mary Nightingale co presenting. All done from Studio 7 at LWT on the South Bank with real windows and proper backdrop of the River Thames.

And despite not being broadcast from Studio 7 in TLS for many, many years, it's still this view that is now digitally imposed in the background of today's ITV London News (basically the modern day London Tonight).

Now that ITV no longer own TLS I sometimes wonder (sad, I know) how they're going to continue to use this view as their background. I know it's not a live feed, but presumably it's re-recorded every so often. Same goes for the now digitally imposed view in the background of This Morning too.

In the end it happened with Carlton, but quite honestly it would have happened if either Thames or LWT (or both) had lost their franchise(s)

In the end it happened with Carlton, but quite honestly it would have happened if either Thames or LWT (or both) had lost their franchise(s)

Interesting that Carlton improved local regional programming but could not match Thames in terms of programming for the ITV network. If you could have the best of Thames and Carlton you would have the perfect service.

Principally thanks to London Tonight, a full one hour local news programme produced by the newly formed LNN and presented by Alastair Stewart, with at times Mary Nightingale co presenting. All done from Studio 7 at LWT on the South Bank with real windows and proper backdrop of the River Thames.

And despite not being broadcast from Studio 7 in TLS for many, many years, it's still this view that is now digitally imposed in the background of today's ITV London News (basically the modern day London Tonight).

Now that ITV no longer own TLS I sometimes wonder (sad, I know) how they're going to continue to use this view as their background. I know it's not a live feed, but presumably it's re-recorded every so often. Same goes for the now digitally imposed view in the background of This Morning too.

I don't think there are any ITV News viewers in the London area who are fooled how the backdrop mysteriously changes either side of an ad break from the bank of monitors with nobody watching them to that of the River Thames, whilst both the desk and presenter quite often remain the same. That is green screen for you. In fact it is about time ITV News had a makeover. They have been using the same desks and backdrops for the past fifteen years.

Principally thanks to London Tonight, a full one hour local news programme produced by the newly formed LNN and presented by Alastair Stewart, with at times Mary Nightingale co presenting. All done from Studio 7 at LWT on the South Bank with real windows and proper backdrop of the River Thames.

And despite not being broadcast from Studio 7 in TLS for many, many years, it's still this view that is now digitally imposed in the background of today's ITV London News (basically the modern day London Tonight).

Now that ITV no longer own TLS I sometimes wonder (sad, I know) how they're going to continue to use this view as their background. I know it's not a live feed, but presumably it's re-recorded every so often. Same goes for the now digitally imposed view in the background of This Morning too.

I don't think there are any ITV News viewers in the London area who are fooled how the backdrop mysteriously changes either side of an ad break from the bank of monitors with nobody watching them to that of the River Thames, whilst both the desk and presenter quite often remain the same. That is green screen for you. In fact it is about time ITV News had a makeover. They have been using the same desks and backdrops for the past fifteen years.

Whilst in the same studio, the ITV News and ITV London News are two different sets - so the presenter does actually have to move to the other side of the studio.

I wasn't suggesting that people believe that's an actual window overlooking the River Thames (although the This Morning one fools more people than you'd think), more querying what they'll do when they can no longer get video of that actual view. Maybe we'll just a different view over London instead of the classic one from the old TLS building on the South Bank.

Maybe we'll just a different view over London instead of the classic one from the old TLS building on the South Bank.

Not necessarily, there are two desks, the large one used for national news and the smaller one for local news. If the lunchtime presenter is sitting at the large desk for the national news, she remains at the same desk to do the five minute London news although the backdrop changes. Apart from the two desks and the platforms they are mounted on, the studio is entirely green. Presenters aren't allowed to wear items of green clothing. When a presenter is interviewing someone who is appearing o a "tv screen", that is illusion, they are in fact looking at the wall. They may be able to see the interviewee on a monitor out of shot of the cameras.
